context: Fed was not only one of the truly great all-time tennis athletes but also perhaps the top promoter of the sport with his warmth, friendliness, and graciousness in defeat. He was poetry in motion.

Great competitors who competed as hard as you can compete against one another....and then liked and respected one another when it was all done.     They probably had the longest the greatest rivalry in sports history, with all due respect to Chris and Martina.  They propelled the men's game to unimaginable heights and quality.  Had Djokovic not come along these 2 would each probably have about 30 majors.
If you have kids playing tennis or any sport‚Ä¶these are the 2 men to emulate. Always class act winners and always gracious in defeat.

context: For me it was Borg.
I once was hit in the head by the racket of Guillermo Vilas as he tried to get to a ball hit in the corner of the court.  My head prevented him from returning the shot.

Roger Federer gave the world,  great classy match after match for more than 2 decades.

context: During the Aggasi/Sampras years, some of us never thought we'd see that kind of rivalry again in our lifetime.  Not only did we get one, but have gotten Djokovic thrown in as well.  81% of all slams in the last 19 years were won by one of these three guys.  Had it not been for an injury or two along the way, that number could have been even higher.  The best part is these guys did it well enough on and off the court, it didn't hurt the game.

replies.context: Pete Sampras was the last classy American tennis great.

Don't use the very few obnoxious American players to paint all American players as classless brats, not every American player is McEnroe or Serena.

Sampras was always very classy and polite. Jim Courier and Michael Chang were as well, Agassi had his moments.  Chris Evert was one of the classiest ladies ever to play the sport, as was Lindsay Davenport, who won three slams, and made the finals of others.  It's too bad Mary Jo Fernandez never won a slam because she was a very classy and sweet lady on the court too, she just ran up against Graf or Seles while those two were dominating, but MJ did make some slam finals.

Very classy exit and what I expected from this fine gentlemen. Too bad all champions can‚Äôt be this gentile when ending their competitive careers.
We have been blessed ‚Äì Federer, Elegance & Class ‚Äì Elegant Ballet on court!; Djokovic, awe-inspiring high-speed 16-wheeler and no brakes!; Nadal ‚Äì sheer bare-knuckle Stubborn Resilience!
FEDAL. The great thing is that, despite their rivalry in tennis, they're actually good friends. They wish each other the best, genuinely. Cheers to that.
I love Federer and Nadal, 2 very classy players!  That was a very heartfelt message from Nadal.  I will miss seeing Federer on tour now, but as with everything else, life moves on ....
Nadal is certainly the best clay court player of all time. But if it were not for the 14  French open titles, he is not in the same conversation with Federer or Djokovic

Finally, a story that doesn't make me want to punch the wall. Two champions in the sport who are fierce competitors but who obviously have enough respect for each other to be civil. Well wishes to both.

These are two of the greatest ever. But beyond their playing abilities they both exemplified a competitive spirit that was well tempered by class. Roger will be greatly missed as will Rafa  when he retires.
Has the most beautiful game ever! Roger will be keenly missed!
Pure class, pretty refreshing

A great athlete and gentleman.   Don't you just love it when a STRAIGHT WHITE MAN shines like that.  I know women tennis now gets rewarded on the same level as men,  but I think they need to up the number of sets they play to win a match if they really are ever going to be considered equal.

If you think about it, had Federer been born 200 yrs ago, none of us today would have ever known about it! Same goes for just about every athlete today! Quite a blessing to play a game for such big money!

I have a lot of friends at Nike in relatively high up roles so they get to meet and hang out with the athletes whenever they come to campus, and to a man/ woman they all said Fed is the coolest, most gracious dude that has come through.  They usually let everyone know a few days prior when they will be on campus, and the joke was you could not get a hair appointment at the Nike salon 10 mins after it was announced, until the day he left.  Apparently even the old ladies show up dressed to the nines on Federer days.  
Was always interesting to hear was cool, and who was.....well let's say not so much.  Everyone was pretty much in agreement who the worst was/ is.
...enjoy your retirement.....class act!
The best ever in my book.  Federer's eye/hand coordination was simply the best I've ever seen.  The guy was silk on the court.  Thank you Roger ... so many great memories watching you play.
I‚Äôve never been a huge tennis fan, but I do remember watching him play some matches and certainly can appreciate what he has accomplished. Wishing him well.
Roger and Rafael are two of the greatest tennis players ever‚Ä¶.talented and gracious. The third guy, not so much.

Playing tennis at an elite level in your 40's  is farrr more challenging than being an elite NFL QB at 45.  Not saying slinging the rock at 45 is anything less than amazing, but tennis is a young man's game.
In a world of Serenas be a Roger.
My brother‚Äôs favourite athlete, and he makes a strong argument. Class act all the way, and a truly astonishing blend of skill, tactics, power, and grace. Brilliant career.
